messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Gap Preserving Reductions Between Reconfiguration Problems1footnote 11footnote 1 A preliminary version of this paper appeared in Proc. 40th Int. Symp. on Theoretical Aspects of Computer Science (STACS), 2023 [Ohs23].

Paper Abstract: Abstract Combinatorial reconfiguration is a growing research field studying reachability and connectivity over the solution space of a combinatorial problem. For example, in SAT Reconfiguration, for a Boolean formula œÜùúë\varphi and its two satisfying truth assignments œÉùóåsubscriptùúéùóå\sigma_{\mathsf{s}} and œÉùóçsubscriptùúéùóç\sigma_{\mathsf{t}}, we are asked to decide if œÉùóåsubscriptùúéùóå\sigma_{\mathsf{s}} can be transformed into œÉùóçsubscriptùúéùóç\sigma_{\mathsf{t}} by repeatedly flipping a single variable assignment at a time, while preserving every intermediate assignment satisfying œÜùúë\varphi. We consider the approximability of optimization variants of reconfiguration problems; e.g., Maxmin SAT Reconfiguration requires to maximize the minimum fraction of satisfied clauses of œÜùúë\varphi during transformation from œÉùóåsubscriptùúéùóå\sigma_{\mathsf{s}} to œÉùóçsubscriptùúéùóç\sigma_{\mathsf{t}}. Solving such optimization variants approximately, we may be able to acquire a reasonable transformation comprising almost-satisfying truth assignments. In this study, we prove a series of gap-preserving reductions to give evidence that a host of reconfiguration problems are PSPACE-hard to approximate, under some plausible assumption. Our starting point is a new working hypothesis called the Reconfiguration Inapproximability Hypothesis (RIH), which asserts that a gap version of Maxmin CSP Reconfiguration is PSPACE-hard. This hypothesis may be thought of as a reconfiguration analogue of the PCP theorem [AS98, ALM+98]. Our main result is PSPACE-hardness of approximating Maxmin 333-SAT Reconfiguration of bounded occurrence under RIH. The crux of its proof is a gap-preserving reduction from Maxmin Binary CSP Reconfiguration to itself of bounded degree. Because a simple application of the degree reduction technique using expander graphs due to Papadimitriou and Yannakakis (J. Comput. Syst. Sci., 1991) [PY91] loses the perfect completeness, we develop a new trick referred to as alphabet squaring, which modifies the alphabet as if each vertex could take a pair of values simultaneously. To accomplish the soundness requirement, we further apply the expander mixing lemma and an explicit family of near-Ramanujan graphs. As an application of the main result, we demonstrate that under RIH, optimization variants of popular reconfiguration problems are PSPACE-hard to approximate, including Nondeterministic Constraint Logic due to Hearn and Demaine (Theor. Comput. Sci., 2005) [HD05, HD09], Independent Set Reconfiguration, Clique Reconfiguration, Vertex Cover Reconfiguration, and 222-SAT Reconfiguration. We finally highlight that all inapproximability results hold unconditionally as long as ‚ÄúPSPACE-hard‚Äù is replaced by ‚ÄúNP-hard.‚Äù

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Explicit construction of linear sized tolerant networks",
        "Proof verification and the hardness of approximation problems",
        "Explicit expanders of every degree and size",
        "Probabilistic checking of proofs: A new characterization of NP",
        "Finding paths between graph colourings: PSPACE-completeness and superpolynomial distances",
        "Shortest reconfiguration of colorings under Kempe changes",
        "Shortest reconfiguration of matchings",
        "Reconfiguration of spanning trees with degree constraint or diameter constraint",
        "Approximating shortest connected graph transformation for trees",
        "Token sliding on split graphs",
        "Reconfiguration of graphs with connectivity constraints",
        "Decremental optimization of dominating sets under the reconfiguration framework",
        "Complexity of token swapping and its variants",
        "Probabilistically checkable debate systems and nonapproximability of PSPACE-hard functions",
        "A short guide to approximation preserving reductions",
        "On approximation scheme preserving reducibility and its applications",
        "Finding paths between 3-colorings",
        "Independent-set reconfiguration thresholds of hereditary graph classes",
        "Parameterized Complexity",
        "The PCP theorem by gap amplification",
        "Parameterized Complexity Theory",
        "Reconfiguring shortest paths in graphs",
        "Some simplified NP-complete graph problems",
        "The connectivity of Boolean satisfiability: Computational and structural dichotomies",
        "Some optimal inapproximability results",
        "PSPACE-completeness of sliding-block puzzles and other problems through the nondeterministic constraint logic model of computation",
        "Games, Puzzles, and Computation",
        "Sorting by short swaps",
        "Approximability of the subset sum reconfiguration problem",
        "On the complexity of reconfiguration problems",
        "Reconfiguration of list edge-colorings in a graph",
        "Shortest reconfiguration of perfect matchings via alternating cycles",
        "Incremental optimization of independent sets under the reconfiguration framework",
        "Reconfiguration of vertex covers in a graph",
        "A compact reformulation of propositional satisfiability as binary constraint satisfaction",
        "Complexity of independent set reconfigurability problems",
        "The complexity of independent set reconfiguration on bipartite graphs",
        "Approximation and hardness of token swapping",
        "Explicit near-Ramanujan graphs of every degree",
        "Introduction to reconfiguration",
        "Gap preserving reductions between reconfiguration problems",
        "Reconfiguration problems on submodular functions",
        "Optimization, approximation, and complexity classes",
        "The complexity of change",
        "Swapping labeled tokens on graphs",
        "Decremental optimization of vertex-coloring under the reconfiguration framework"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Gap Preserving Reductions Between Reconfiguration Problems1footnote 11footnote 1 A preliminary version of this paper appeared in Proc. 40th Int. Symp. on Theoretical Aspects of Computer Science (STACS), 2023 [Ohs23]., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
